it is a brisk weekday morning in
Portland Oregon and the daily commute
gets underway the city's streets and
bridges are crowded with cars buses
streetcars and Light Rail trains and
another popular vehicle quicker and
cheaper than taking the bus
Portland's long been known as one of the
nation's leading cycling cities
Portland's known for being being very
green and progressive here bikes provide
more than recreation and sport they are
a significant means of transportation a
census report released this year found
that a higher percentage of people in
Portland commute by bike than in any
other American city now the city is
capitalizing on its reputation it is
building a cycling economy we have some
of the best custom-made bike frame
manufacturers in the United States we
have a whole industry that has sort of
grown up around the bike usage that
really was sort of the start of the bike
culture Portland is a bike town it's
known as a bike town around the round
the world and one of the one of the best
places to be if you're a cyclist that
was Tony Pereira his one man bike making
business is part of the city's growing
cycling industry it includes bike makers
clothing manufacturers even consultants
who advise other cities on how to become
more bike friendly I've always loved
bikes and I've been an avid mountain
biker since the 80s and it when it all
kind of first began the growth of
cycling is meant changed for the city
and at times controversy in October two
cyclists were killed when they were hit
by trucks in separate accidents the
deaths called attention to the growing
challenge of managing traffic as bike
popularity stores and cyclists demand
respect on the roads it was the fifth
generation that finally work Andy
Newlands first started making bikes here
in the 1970s and he's widely considered
to be the first person to bring the
handmade industry to Portland
back then he rarely saw fellow cyclists
on the street in 1970 I don't think it
would have passed the person today I was
I wrote across town came back across the
Hawthorne Bridge I'll bet there were 30
other cyclists piled up they just kept
coming and coming and coming
much of this growth has been organic so
to speak cultural and economic extension
of the cities character its residents
inclination to conserve energy protect
the environment and stay fit and while
many writers say they like the area's
moderate climate and relatively gentle
terrain cycling stature in Portland can
also be traced directly to support from
the city intentions are to be as a
sustainable city as possible the city of
Portland in the last sort of 15 or 20
years has probably invested around
twenty to twenty five million dollars to
increase our bike infrastructure
everything from bike lanes to bike paths
to better lighting to help acres
navigate through the city streets
they've also spent money to help local
businesses like Tony Pereira's learn how
to better manage their operations and
promote themselves the classical spring
building is definitely a very small
niche market a lot of the frame builders
get into this because they love bicycles
not because they want business near one
of the city's ubiquitous coffee shops
cyclists praise the effort the city has
done a great job in planning it's a
community that supports cyclists so
there's a certain amount of awareness
amongst drivers to which is great I
think it's a combination of that and
it's just a pretty friendly city to
begin with it's very well laid out and
there's a lot of bike lanes this is not
only rambling one of the newest local
bike makers I am NOT a native of
Portland both my parents grew up here
and so I always come from California and
visit and I realized that California
didn't offer me the ability to bike
anywhere and everywhere as a first-class
citizen in the way that Portland does
here is like if you're riding a bike
you're really traveling in the
vernacular it's what people do here
